description.narrative:
Olof Palme International Center (OPC) har inkommit med en ansökan till Sida om finansiering av 6,2 miljoner SEK för att genomföra "Medborgarnas deltagande för ansvarsfullt och öppet styre mot social rättvisa i Nord Makedonien" under perioden januari 2020 - december 2021.
Insatsen syftar till att stärka det civila samhällets organisationers kapacitet och legitimitet och stödja aktiviteter som säkerställer deltagande i politiska, sociala och ekonomiska processer och ansvarsutkrävande av ansvarstagare. Organisationer i det civila samhället kommer att mobilisera medborgarna och öka deltagandet i beslutsprocesser, förbättra öppenheten och ansvarsutkrävande, samt säkerställa respekten för socioekonomiska rättigheter.
Förväntade resultat av insatsen: 1. Programmet avser att se partnerorganisationer stärka deras legitimitet, bygga allianser för gemensamma åtgärder för att påverka politiska dagordningar och ha kapacitet att övervaka genomförandet av politiska beslut. 2. Programmet har för avsikt att se stärkta medborgare och civilsamhällets organisationer som är organiserade, aktivt deltar i och påverkar beslutsprocesser, kräver öppenhet och ansvarutkrävande av ansvarstagare. 3. Programmet har för avsikt att se arsvarstagare följa bestämmelser som rör transparens och ansvarsutkrävande, samarbeta med relevanta delar av det civila samhället och inkludera dem i beslutsprocesser.
OPCs samarbete bygger på stöd till enskilda projekt såväl som till nätverk och allianser som samlas kring gemensamma frågor/komponenter i programmet.

Olof Palme International Center (OPC) has applied to Sida for funding of 6,2 million SEK to carry out the "Citizens´ participation for accountable and transparent governance towards social justice in North Macedonia" during the period January 2020 - December 2021.
The intervention aims to strengthen the capacity and legitimacy of civil society organisations and support activities that ensure the participatory nature of political, social and economic processes and the accountability of duty bearers. Civil society organisations will mobilize citizens and increase participation in decision-making processes, improve transparency and accountability and ensure respect for socio-economic rights.
Expected outcomes of the intervention: 1. The programme intends to see partner organisations strengthen their legitimacy, build alliances for joint actions to influence policy agendas and have capacities to monitor the implementation of political decisions. 2. The programme intends to see empowered citizens and civil society organisations be organised and actively participate and influence decision-making processes, demanding transparency and accountability of duty bearers. 3. The programme intends to see duty-bearers abide to regulations related to transparency and accountability, cooperate with relevant parts of civil society and include them in decision-making processes.
OPC´s cooperation builds on support to individual Projects as well as to networks and Alliances gathered around common issues/components of the program.
The direct target group is programme partner organisations. The indirect target groups, reached by the programme partners, are citizens/organized citizen groups and duty bearers.

The overall objective of the intervention (vision) is to contribute to: Political and social processes in North Macedonia that are transparent and participatory,reflecting the rights and interests of empowered and organized citizens that hold dutybearers accountable. The project objective (mission) is: To strengthen the capacity and legitimacy of civil society organisations and supportactivities that ensure the participatory nature of political, social and economic processesand the accountability of duty bearers. description.narrative: From CoP June 2021: Below is a summary of results that the partner have reached, focusing on the period 1 January - 31 December 2020. In 2020, OPC continued to support the strengthening of democratic processes and civil society organizations by working with five partner organisations: SIER (Trade Union of Industry, Energy and Mining of Macedonia), MKC Bitola (Youth Cultural Center Bitola), Multikultura Tetovo, Glasen Tekstilec and NGO Info-center. The period was strongly characterized by the outbreak of Covid-19. For the initial months of the pandemic, OPC hosted weekly online meetings to be able to act quickly to partners needs for adjustments of plans and/or budgets. Although the pandemic brought uncertainties for OPC's partner organisations and their work, the annual report for 2020 shows that to a large extent they were able to adapt to online working methods and focused on monitoring good governance practices. Despite restrictions due to the pandemic, OPC's partners provided spaces for interaction and demanded accountability of the duty bearers in addressing citizens’ issues, for instance around lack of access to information and lack of transparency of institutions. Only some activities planned by the partners of OPC had to be postponed. However, when it comes to the regional component of the programme, the pandemic was affecting its overall implementation as regional network meetings and study visits to Sweden had to be postponed. The narrative report of 2020 primarily focused on the progress linked to OPC's direct boundary partners (their partner organisations). In this regards, steps have been taken towards the outcome challenge: “The programme intends to see partner organisations strengthen their legitimacy, build alliances for joint actions to influence policy agendas and have capacities to monitor the implementation of political decisions.” and its four target areas: 1) sustainability and legitimacy, 2) use of participatory mechanisms, 3) coalition and networking, 4) monitoring and advocacy. Within the first target area, SIER provided capacity trainings to its union representatives working with health and safety issues concerning how to deal with the pandemic situation at their workplaces. Through this work, SIER not only raised their internal capacities but also strengthened their public image and reputation among workers, being the first union to offering assistance in the urgent crisis situation. SIER increased its membership base with 220 new members - a good indication that the activities in the project are showing results and that the sustanability of the organisation is improving. In the second target area, MKC Bitola enabled reactivation of Local Economic-Social Councils (LESCs) in five municipalities (Bitola, Struga, Shtip, Tetovo and Gostivar) through broad consultations and participation of all stakeholders and social parters in community forums and panel discussions. Within the third target area, the association Multikultura Tetovo created a legal clinic and together with the Faculty of Law of the South East European University, providing free legal services. They also joined the civic initiative “Boll mo”, in order to offer free legal aid to citizens in need. In the forth and final target area, Glasen Tekstilec took part in regular weekly meetings in working groups created and led by the Minister of Labour and Social Policy involving the Director of the Inspection Council, Director of Public Revenue Office and other relevant institutions, to discuss pandemic measures. Glasen Tekstilec monitored the implementation of laws, measures and recommendations and the effects for workers in the textile industry. They also participated in a working group for drafting a new Labour law together with representatives of trade unions, employers' organisations and other representatives of the business community. In addition and also connected to the fourth target area, the NGO Info-center has during 2020 assessed and monitored the anti-corruption policies and practices, as well as the functioning of the local inspectorates. They prepared a recommendation paper, held meetings with the mayors and other officials, organized workshops for municipalities’ administration and officials, focus groups, series of press releases, infographics, media articles etc. According to the annual report of 2020, the municipalities have been very responsive and taken into consideration the findings and the recommendations from NGO Info-center and its local allies. Altogether, OPC has reported that the pandemic challenged them and their partner organisations to quickly adapt to new circumstances in order to ensure a continuation in the implementation of the programme. Moreover, in this challenging time, OPC also showed that they were able to handle the situation well and, by working in new ways, still making progress towards the overall aim of the programme.
